title: 110_hr6568
content: The Act is titled the "Tom Lantos Pulmonary Hypertension Research and Education Act of 2008" and includes sections on research and increasing awareness of pulmonary hypertension. Section 101 focuses on expanding and intensifying activities related to research on pulmonary hypertension. The Congress emphasizes the need for continued aggressive research on pulmonary hypertension, including expanding understanding of its causes and finding a cure. Activities may involve basic research on the etiology and causes of pulmonary hypertension. The text chunk discusses research on the relationship between scleroderma, sickle cell anemia, and pulmonary hypertension, clinical research for new treatments, support for training new clinicians, and education programs for the public. The Secretary will provide updates on pulmonary hypertension research at the National Institutes of Health as required by section 403 of the Public Health Service Act. Increasing awareness of pulmonary hypertension through promoting public awareness. The Secretary will conduct an educational campaign to raise public awareness about pulmonary hypertension, including information on symptoms, incidence, early diagnosis, and treatment options. Materials may be distributed through print, video, and web-based platforms. The Secretary is encouraged to disseminate information on pulmonary hypertension through a national nonprofit entity. A report to Congress is due by September 30, 2009, on the activities. $2,500,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2009-2011 for this purpose. Promoting awareness among health care professionals is emphasized in Section 202. The Secretary will conduct an educational campaign to raise awareness of pulmonary hypertension among health care providers, including information on symptoms, early diagnosis, diagnostic criteria, and FDA-approved therapies. Targeted providers include cardiologists, pulmonologists, rheumatologists, primary care physicians, pediatricians, and nurse practitioners. The Secretary is encouraged to disseminate information on pulmonary hypertension through a national nonprofit entity. A report to Congress is due by September 30, 2009, on the activities. $2,500,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2009-2011 for this purpose. The House of Representatives passed the document on September 25, 2008.
